nodes.name: Load Email Queue
nodes.notes:
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
  NODE 2: LOAD EMAIL QUEUE FROM DATABASE  â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
  Queries the email_queue table to retrieve all
  jobs processed in the current workflow run.

  What this node does:
  - Connects to n8n data table: "email_queue"
  - Filters by workflow_run_id from parent
    workflow (or manual trigger)
  - Returns ALL jobs across ALL companies from
    this workflow run
  - Each row is one complete job with HTML card
    and metadata

  Table schema (columns stored):

  1. workflow_run_id (number):
     - PRIMARY FILTER FIELD (indexed for
       performance)
     - Groups all jobs from single workflow run
     - Example: 67890
     - This is how we know which jobs belong together

  2. recommendation (string):
     - AI's recommendation category
     - Values: EXCELLENT_MATCH | GOOD_MATCH |
       CONSIDER | POOR_FIT | REJECT
     - Used for filtering and grouping in next node
     - Determines badge color in email

  3. overall_score (number):
     - AI's numeric score (1-10)
     - Primary sort field (higher = better match)
     - Used to order jobs in email (best first)

  4. html_card (string):
     - Complete, formatted HTML job card
     - Self-contained, ready to insert in email
     - Generated by Loop Jobs workflow's Format
       Job Card node
     - Size: ~2-5KB per job
     - Contains: title, company, salary,
       location, AI assessment, scores

  5. job_id (string):
     - Unique identifier from Apify
     - Links back to raw jobs_test_1 table
     - Used for deduplication and tracking

  6. company_name (string):
     - Company posting the job
     - Example: "Anthropic", "OpenAI", "Google"
     - Could be used for company-based grouping
       (not currently used)

  7. job_title (string):
     - Job title for reference
     - Example: "Senior Technical Product Manager"
     - Stored separately for quick reference
       without parsing HTML

  Next node receives:
  - Array of job objects
  - Each with html_card field
  - Each with scoring metadata
  - Ready for aggregation and sorting

  Next node: Aggregate and Sort Jobs

nodes.name: Aggregate and Sort Jobs
nodes.notes:
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• NODE 3: AGGREGATE AND SORT JOBS Purpose: Organize jobs by score and category for optimal email presentation â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• ARCHITECTURAL NOTE: This node transforms the data structure from: - MANY ITEMS (20 individual jobs) â†’ ONE ITEM (aggregated summary) - Individual job cards â†’ Combined HTML string - Raw data â†’ Presentation-ready data STEP 1: Get all jobs from database query $input.all() returns array of ALL items from Load Email Queue node Example: 20 items (jobs) from email_queue table Each item: { json: { workflow_run_id, recommendation, overall_score, html_card, ... } } â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• CATEGORIZATION Group jobs by AI recommendation for summary statistics â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• EXCELLENT_MATCH: Top-tier jobs - perfect fit across all dimensions Seniority + Domain + Technical Depth + Location + Compensation all high const excellentMatches = allJobs.filter(job => job.json.recommendation === 'EXCELLENT_MATCH'); Example: 3 jobs with scores 9-10 GOOD_MATCH / STRONG_MATCH: Strong candidates - good fit with minor gaps NOTE: AI prompt uses 'GOOD_MATCH' but checking both for compatibility One or two dimensions slightly lower but overall strong fit const strongMatches = allJobs.filter(job => job.json.recommendation === 'STRONG_MATCH' || job.json.recommendation === 'GOOD_MATCH' ); CONSIDER: Possible matches - worth reviewing despite notable gaps Multiple dimensions are acceptable but not strong User should review carefully before applying const considerJobs = allJobs.filter(job => job.json.recommendation === 'CONSIDER'); POOR_FIT: Not recommended - significant mismatches Multiple critical dimensions fail (wrong level, location, domain) Included for completeness but not highlighted in email const poorFits = allJobs.filter(job => job.json.recommendation === 'POOR_FIT'); â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• SORTING Primary sort: overall_score descending (best jobs first) â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• Sort by score: highest to lowest This ensures best matches appear at top of email User sees most relevant jobs first without scrolling const sortedJobs = allJobs.sort((a, b) => b.json.overall_score - a.json.overall_score ); Result: Jobs ordered 10 â†’ 9 â†’ 9 â†’ 8 â†’ 8 â†’ 7 â†’ 7 â†’ 6 â†’ ... Result: Single string with all job cards and visual spacing Size: ~40-100KB for 20 jobs (2-5KB per card) â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• OUTPUT STRUCTURE Create single aggregated object with statistics and combined HTML â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• return [{ json: { // === SUMMARY COUNTS === // These drive the email header statistics // and dynamic subject line total_jobs: allJobs.length, // 20 - Total jobs in digest excellent_count: excellentMatches.length, // 3 - Best matches strong_count: strongMatches.length, // 8 - Good matches consider_count: considerJobs.length, // 6 - Review carefully poor_count: poorFits.length, // 3 - Not recommended // === COMPLETE HTML CONTENT === // All job cards concatenated with spacers, // sorted by score job_cards_html: jobCardsHtml, // Size: ~40-100KB for 20 jobs // Contains: Complete, formatted HTML ready // to insert into email body // === WORKFLOW TRACKING === // Preserve workflow_run_id for email // footer and debugging workflow_run_id: allJobs[0].json.workflow_run_id // Safe to access [0] because we know we // have jobs from query // All jobs have same workflow_run_id anyway } }]; WHAT GETS OUTPUT: Single item (not 20) with aggregated data: { total_jobs: 20, excellent_count: 3, strong_count: 8, consider_count: 6, poor_count: 3, job_cards_html: "

nodes.name: Build Email
nodes.notes:
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
  NODE 4: BUILD EMAIL (HTML EMAIL GENERATOR)  â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
  Purpose: Create professional, responsive HTML email with job digest
  Input: Single aggregated item with statistics and combined HTML
  Output: Complete email with dynamic subject line and formatted HTML body

  Key features:
  - Dynamic subject line based on job quality
  - Professional HTML email template
  - Responsive design for mobile/desktop
  - Color-coded statistics (green/blue/amber/gray)
  - Conditional content (highlight for excellent matches)
  - Email client compatible (inline styles)

  Next node: Send Jobs Email

  NODE 5: SEND EMAIL (SMTP DELIVERY)
  Purpose: Deliver formatted HTML email digest
  to recipient
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

  SMTP Configuration:
  - From: "[Email Name <email@address>]"
  - To: Dynamic from Start node (see below)
  - Subject: {{ $json.subject }} (from Build Email)
  - Body: {{ $json.html_body }} (formatted HTML)

  CRITICAL: Recipient Address Uses [1] Index

  {{ $('Start').all()[1].json.full_name + ' <' +
     $('Start').all()[1].json.email + '>' }}

  Parent workflow passes TWO items to Start node:
  - Item [0]: Workflow summary (workflow_run_id,
    companies_processed)
  - Item [1]: User configuration (full_name,
    email, preferences)

  This node accesses Item [1] for recipient info.
